case_name: State of Kerala v. Owners of private forest lands

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1938 of 1972 appealed from Kerala High Court judgment dated 21st June 1972 in O.P. No. 3771 of 1971.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1938 of 1972. Appeal from the judgment and order dated the 21st June, 1972, ,,if the Kerala High Court at Emakulam in O.P. No. 3771 of 1971.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1416 of 1972 from Kerala High Court judgment dated 21st June 1972 in O.P. No. 3858 of 1971.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 1416 of 1972. Appeal from the judgment and order dated the 21st June, 1972 of the Kerala High Court at Ernakulam in O.P. No. 3858 of 1971.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1417 of 1972 from Kerala High Court judgment dated 21st June 1972 in O.P. No. 4036 of 1971 and Writ Petitions Nos. 151 to 198 of 1971 under Art. 32.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 1417 of 1972 Appeal from the judgment and order dated the 21st June,, 1972 of the Kerala High Court at Ernakulam in O.P. No. 4036 of 1971 and Writ Petition Nos. 151, 152, 153, 176, 177, 178. 179, 180, 181, 182, 186, 187, 188, 189, 198 of 1971.

facts.text: Writ Petitions filed under Article 32 by owners and lessees of large tracts of forest lands.

anchor.surface_text: The Writ Petitions are filed in this Court under Article 32 of the Constitution by several Owners and or lessees of large tracts of forest lands.

facts.text: Kerala High Court held Act not protected by Article 31A, declared unconstitutional, reported in A.I.R. 1973 Kerala 36.

anchor.surface_text: The Civil, Appeals are filed by the State, of Kerala from the judgment and order of a full bench of the Kerala High Court  Reported in A.I.R. 1973, Kerala 36  in petitions filed in that companyrt challenging the Act.

facts.text: Lands are private forest lands in former Malabar District transferred to Kerala by States Reorganisation Act 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The lands involved are private forest lands situated in the former Malabar District which, after the States Re- organization Act, 1956, stood transferred from the old State of Madras to the new State of Kerala.

facts.text: Kerala Private Forests Vesting and Assignment Act 26 of 1971 challenged as violative of Articles 14, 19(1)(f)(g), 31.

anchor.surface_text: All the above cases involve a challenged to the Kerala Private Forests  Vesting and Assignment  Act 26 of 1971  hereinafter called the Act  on the ground that the Act as a whole was violative of Articles 14, 19 1   f   g  and 31 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Act vests forest lands in State as measure of agrarian reform.

anchor.surface_text: As a result of the Act referred to above, these forest lands vest in the State, allegedly, as a measure of agrarian reform.

facts.text: Appointed day for vesting is 10th May 1971.

anchor.surface_text: By Section 1 the Act is made to extend to the whole of the State of Kerala and is deemed to have companye into force on the 10th day of May, 1971.

facts.text: Private forests vest in Government free from encumbrances from appointed day per Section 3(1).

anchor.surface_text: Section 3 is important. Private forests to vest in Government 1  Notwithstanding anything companytained in any other law for the time being in force, or in any companytract or other document, but subject to the provisions of sub- sections  2  and  3 , with effect on and from the appointed day,

facts.text: No compensation payable for vesting per Section 9.

anchor.surface_text: Section 9 provides that No companypensation shall be payable for the vesting in the Government of any private forest or for the extinguishment of the right, tide and interest of the owner or any other person in any private forest under sub-section 1  of section 3.

facts.text: Government to assign private forests to agriculturists, agricultural laborers etc. after reservations per Section 10.

anchor.surface_text: Section 10 Assignment of Private forests.- 1  The Government shall, after reserving such extent of the private forests vested in the Government under sub-section  1  of section 3 or of the lands companyprised in such private forests as may be necessary for purposes directed towards the promotion of agriculture or the welfare of the agricultural population or for purposes ancillary thereto,

facts.text: Assignment to be completed within two years from publication per Section 11.

anchor.surface_text: Section 11 is important. It reads Assignment to be made within two years.-Assignment of the private forests or the lands companyprised therein under section 10 shall, as far as may be, companypleted within two years from the date of publication of this Act in the Gazette.

facts.text: Private forests in Malabar held in janmam rights.

anchor.surface_text: It was submitted that the private forests in Malabar are held in janman right and hence they are an ,estate within the meaning of sub-clause  i .

facts.text: High Court concluded forest lands not agricultural lands, scheme not genuine agrarian reform.

anchor.surface_text: Having regard to our companyclusions that forest lands in the State of Kerala, cannot generally be regarded as agricultural lands and, therefore, cannot be the subject of agrarian reform and that the scheme of agrarian reform envisaged by the impugned Act is number real or genuine but only illusory,

facts.text: Approximately 28% of Kerala land area constitutes forest lands.

anchor.surface_text: In para 4 of his affidavit he says Approximately 28 per cent of the total land area in the Kerala State companystitutes forest lands.

facts.text: Private forests in Malabar area about 1,200 sq. miles or 7.5 lakh acres owned by 116 private individuals per 1945 survey.

anchor.surface_text: It was estimated that the total extent of private forests in Malabar area would companye to about 1,200 sq. miles, i.e. about 7.5 lakh acres As per the Survey companyducted by the Madras Government in the year 1945, private forest lands in Malabar area,

facts.text: Forest lands in Kerala capable of cultivation of food and cash crops.

anchor.surface_text: Then he proceeds to say, the forest lands in Kerala are agricultural lands and can be put to cultivation of various food and cash crops.

facts.text: Owners or contractors clear-felled forests for food crops like coffee, coconut, pepper.

anchor.surface_text: It is also pertinent to, place before this Honble Court the fact that in large tracts of areas which had been already clear-felled by the owners of the private forests or their companytractors, food-crops like companyfee, companyonut. pepper, etc have been raised companyverting them into such food crop plantations.

facts.text: Private forests held in janmam rights, which are estates under Article 31A(2)(i).

anchor.surface_text: It is number disputed that all the private forests. with which we are number companycerned are held in Janmam right. Janmam rights being an ,estate are liable to be acquired by the State under Article 31A 1   a  as a necessary step to the implementation of agrarian reform.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds Act protected by Article 31A, constitutionally valid.

anchor.surface_text: In the result the appeals are allowed and the Writ Petitions dismissed. It is declared that the Kerala Private Forests  Vesting and Assignment  Act, 1971 is companystitutionally valid.

facts.text: One company purchased 30,000 acres for Rs. 75 lakhs relying on govt assurance not to acquire for 60 years.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, the Company purchased 30,000 acres of private forests from the Nilabhuri KovilaKannan estate. for Rs. 75/- lakhs and, therefore, it was argued that, so far as the companypany is companycerned, the-agreement number to legislate should operate as equitable estoppel against the State.

facts.text: Government distributing 3 lakh acres of forest lands for agriculturists.

anchor.surface_text: The Government is currently distributing 3 lakh acres of forest lands for settlement of agriculturists.

anchor.surface_text: Once we find the legislative area is barricaded by art. 31A, it cannot be breached by arts. 14, 19 and 31 and judicial break-in is constitutionally interdicted.

holdings.text: The Kerala Private Forests Vesting and Assignment Act, 1971 is constitutionally valid, protected by Article 31A.

anchor.surface_text: In the result the appeals are allowed and the Writ Petitions dismissed. It is declared that the Kerala Private Forests  Vesting and Assignment  Act, 1971 is companystitutionally valid.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Janmam rights constitute 'estate' under Art 31A(2)(a)(i); s10 provides genuine scheme of agrarian reform by assignment to agriculturists etc.; analogous to upheld Kannan Devan Act.

holdings.text: Private forests held in janmam rights constitute an 'estate' under Article 31A(2)(a)(i).

anchor.surface_text: It is number disputed that all the private forests. with which we are number companycerned are held in Janmam right. Janmam rights being an ,estate are liable to be acquired by the State under Article 31A 1   a

holdings.reasoning_summary: Janmam rights are hereditary proprietorship included in inclusive definition of 'estate' under Art 31A(2)(a)(i) as per precedents like Kavalappara Kottarathil Kochuni.

holdings.text: The scheme under section 10 of the Act constitutes a genuine scheme of agrarian reform.

anchor.surface_text: What then is the scheme of agrarian reform envisaged in the impugned Act? ... That scheme as envisaged in this section was upheld by this Court as a scheme for agrarian reform

holdings.reasoning_summary: Assignment after reservations to agriculturists, laborers etc. for cultivation promotes agriculture and rural welfare; time-bound by s11; upheld similar scheme in Kannan Devan Hills Act.

holdings.text: Section 9 providing no compensation is valid under Article 31A.

anchor.surface_text: Once we find the legislative area is barricaded by art. 31A, it cannot be breached by arts. 14, 19 and 31 and judicial break-in is constitutionally interdicted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art 31A immunizes from challenges under Arts 14,19,31 including compensation requirement when acquiring estates for agrarian reform.

holdings.text: The High Court erred in holding that forest lands cannot be subject of agrarian reform and scheme illusory.

anchor.surface_text: Having regard to our conclusions that forest lands in the State of Kerala, cannot generally be regarded as agricultural lands and, therefore, cannot be the subject of agrarian reform

holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence shows forests capable of agriculture; janmam estates acquirable; s10 genuine scheme; rejects High Court reasons like lease vs registry, trees appropriation.

holdings.text: The scheme under s10 is real and genuine, not illusory.

anchor.surface_text: Section 10 Assignment of Private forests.- 1  The Government shall, after reserving such extent of the private forests vested in the Government under sub-section  1  of section 3

holdings.reasoning_summary: Detailed assignment to specified beneficiaries; reservations for ag promotion; welfare fund from trees; feasible without prior survey; rejects High Court objections.

holdings.text: The Act is not a piece of colorable legislation.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Legislature competent; protected by Art 31A; prior bill with compensation irrelevant to validity.

holdings.text: Agreement by government not to legislate does not create equitable estoppel against the State.

anchor.surface_text: We do number see how an agreement of the Government can preclude legislation on the subject. The High Court has rightly pointed out that the surrender by the, Government

holdings.reasoning_summary: Government cannot surrender legislative power by agreement; applies to specific party.

holdings.text: Agrarian reform encompasses broad rural welfare, production increase beyond mere land distribution.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Dynamic concept including economic units, credit, irrigation, marketing, training; s10 fits; per constitutional history and precedents.

precedents.citation: 1969 K.L.T. 320 V. Venugopala Varma Rajaa v. Controller of Estate Duty, Kerala

anchor.surface_text: In the Judgment reported in 1969 K.L.T. 320 V. Venugopala Varma Rajaa v. Controller of Estate Duty, Kerala a division bench of the High Court has held that in the absence of exceptional circumstances such as the land being. entirely rocky and barren for other reasons, all forests lands- in the State are agricultural lands in the sense that they can be prudently and profitably exploited for agriculturing purposes.

precedents.case_name: V. Venugopala Varma Rajaa v. Controller of Estate Duty, Kerala
precedents.cited_proposition: forest lands in Kerala are agricultural lands capable of being prudently and profitably exploited for agricultural purposes
precedents.cited_holding: all forests lands in the State are agricultural lands in the sense that they can be prudently and profitably exploited for agricultural purposes

precedents.citation: V. Venugopala Varma Rajaa v. Controller of Estate Duty, Kerala 1 1969 K. L. T. 230

anchor.surface_text: what a bench of the Kerala- High Court said in V. Venugopala Varma Rajaa v. Controller of Estate Duty, Kerala 1 in para 6 of the judgment. It is well-known that the extensive areas of different varieties of plantations that we have got in this State were once forest lands and it is also equally well- known that year.

precedents.case_name: V. Venugopala Varma Rajaa v. Controller of Estate Duty, Kerala
precedents.cited_proposition: forest lands in Kerala can be converted into plantations and are agricultural lands
precedents.cited_holding: It is well-known that the extensive areas of different varieties of plantations that we have got in this State were once forest lands... all forest lands in this State are agricultural lands

precedents.citation: Kavalappara Kottarathil Kochuni and others v. The State of Madras and others 1 1960 3 S. C. R. 887

anchor.surface_text: Janman rights in the States of Madras and Kerala are, as explained by Subba Rao, J. in Kavalappara Kottarathil Kochuni and others v. The State of Madras and others 1 rights of hereditary proprietorship in land. These rights, like the rights created by grant of jagir or inam relating to land, which included agricultural lands or waste lands or forests and hills
